{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3603645,"name":"Collyn Diamond","username":"123pdrinter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/123pdrinter/{size}/248529_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-25T15:08:55.830Z","cooked":"

What is the fastest way to calibrate PV Cameras? I want to accurately calibrate each of my 4 cameras, but I don’t want to sit around taking pictures all day. I think I saw a post where someone mentioned recording a video and extracting the frames to be used as calibration images, but I cant find it. If that’s possible, how can I do something like that?

123pdrinter:

I don’t want to sit around taking pictures all day

Using the client, it should take maybe a minute per camera

Affordable Charuco Calibration Targets General Forum
Looking for a reliable and affordable way to calibrate your cameras for 2025? I’m excited to share a new product: Charuco Calibration Targets, designed specifically for teams looking to achieve professional-quality camera calibration without breaking the bank. Why These Targets? Flat and Durable: Made from 6mm aluminum composite, these targets stay flat, ensuring consistent and accurate calibration results. Cost-Effective: Comparable to professional-grade targets but at a fraction of the pric…

You might try WPIcal. It uses MrCal. Probably easiest before mounting cameras so you can record video while moving camera. It may be slightly easier but making sure the resolution, board size, charuco pattern is all set correctly.

This time I just did the PV calibration using a computer monitor and moved the monitor around with cameras already on the robot. I only calibrated at the target resolution I wanted to use to save time. I recall the last camera calibrated to 0.25px with 30-40 pictures.

PhotonVision uses MrCal’s algorithm internally afaik.

Sorry, I should be more specific. I think WPICal uses MrCal also, so if you use it to calibrate with a video I think you can just import the camera calibration into photonvision. However, I haven’t tested that.
